Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status
Story: I stood in the kitchen, my stepmother’s voice echoing in my mind. “You’re the eldest now. It’s your turn to lead the family ceremony. Your father would have wanted you to honor our traditions.” Her eyes searched mine, full of hope and expectation. I nodded, feeling the weight of her words settle on my shoulders. My phone buzzed in my pocket, snapping me back to my other world. A customer’s message flashed on the screen: “Where’s my package? I need it urgently.” I knew I had to respond quickly, with the usual calm professionalism my boss expected. But my hands trembled, torn between crafting the perfect reply and rehearsing the ceremonial lines I barely remembered. My stepmother peeked in, reminding me to change into the traditional attire. The customer’s impatience grew with each passing minute. I felt trapped, pulled in two directions—one demanding I honor my new family, the other insisting I maintain my job’s standards. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, caught between duty and obligation, unsure which role to answer first.
